messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: <tumb@...>


>
>
> Is there any recommended (or better yet documented) ideal level of
> testing?
> Our company is working on adopting XP and perhaps test driven practises.
> We have a question about whether certain groups are testing too little or
> too much. How, if at all, do you determine what's too little or too much?

To answer the original question, here is what the efforts I have been
involved in have done:

1) Get an early testing effort started. This is very important. Just get
something started. If you can't convince management to do TDD, then convince
them to do some form of unit testing, even if it isn't the developer
themselves testing. Later on you can get TDD started at some level.

2) Polish up your tests to be effective and efficient at finding bugs.

3) Add new unit test cases to cover bugs you find later so that if the code
is changed that particular bug is tested for on each build.

4) Conduct various coverage metrics. If you don't measure you won't know,
you will just be guessing. One hundred percent coverage is desireable, but
may not always be attainable, especially in some modes, but by all means
measure it.

5) There are metrics you can use to measure the number and severity of bugs
that are being found or that exist in the code at any given time. You will
see patterns depending on the development and testing methodologies. In a
mature process you will see upturns in bug numbers (maybe in severity
depending on the maturity of the code) as new features and logic are
introduced, then maybe plateaus, and hopefully drop offs. This is where the
metrics require some human interpretation. As you gain experience with the
metrics and the code, you will gain confidence in what quantity and quality
of bugs are acceptable for the codebase.

Lauren
